title: 115_s1402
content: The "School Food Modernization Act" may provide loan guarantees and grants for improvements to school lunch facilities under the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act. The "School Food Modernization Act" defines terms like durable equipment, eligible entity, and infrastructure for the improvement of school lunch facilities. The "School Food Modernization Act" defines terms such as local educational agency, school food authority, and tribal organization. It also authorizes loan guarantees for infrastructure improvements and durable equipment necessary for healthy school lunch programs. The "School Food Modernization Act" authorizes loan guarantees for infrastructure improvements and durable equipment to assist eligible entities in providing healthy meals through a school lunch program. Loan guarantees are issued on a competitive basis, with preferences given to entities demonstrating substantial need for infrastructure improvement. The Secretary will oversee infrastructure improvement and equipment purchases with loan guarantees, not exceeding 80% of the loan amount. Fees will cover administrative costs for the program. The Secretary will provide loan guarantees for infrastructure projects based on risk premiums associated with the loan, considering Treasury obligations, market conditions, project support, and loan guarantee amount. Funding for loan guarantees will be reserved by the Secretary. The Secretary will reserve $300,000,000 of loan guarantee authority for community facility guaranteed loans. Additionally, up to 5% of the funds may be used for technical assistance. In fiscal year 2018, the Secretary will provide grants to eligible entities for purchasing equipment and infrastructure to improve food safety and serve healthier meals. Priority will be given to entities in states with existing grant funding mechanisms or appropriations for this purpose. The Secretary will provide grants to eligible entities for purchasing equipment and infrastructure to improve food safety and serve healthier meals. The Federal share of costs for assistance funded through a grant awarded under this subsection shall not exceed 80 percent of the total. Priority will be given to entities in states with existing grant funding mechanisms or appropriations for this purpose. Eligible entities must identify and meet an unmet local or community need through public-private partnerships or provision of kitchen or cafeteria usage by community organizations. The Secretary will provide grants to eligible entities for purchasing equipment and infrastructure to improve food safety and serve healthier meals. The Federal share of costs for assistance funded through a grant awarded under this subsection shall not exceed 80 percent of the total. An eligible entity must provide matching support in cash or in-kind contributions. The Secretary may waive requirements if undue hardship would result. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal year 2018 and each. The Secretary may allocate up to 5% of the funds each fiscal year for providing technical assistance to applicants in preparing applications and securing financing packages. SEC. 21A. TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR SCHOOL FOOD SERVICE PERSONNEL. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to provide training and technical assistance for school food service personnel. The Secretary will award grants to third-party training institutions to provide training and assistance for school food service personnel to meet nutrition standards and improve the school lunch program. Eligible institutions must demonstrate effective training capacity. The eligible institutions must have prior experience in providing training and technical assistance programming to school food service personnel, developing educational training tools on child and school nutrition topics, and delivering cost-efficient training at proximate locations. The Secretary will assist institutions in publicizing and disseminating training materials. The Federal share of costs for training shall not exceed 80%, and matching support is required from third-party training institutions. The Secretary shall oversee training and technical assistance funded through grants to ensure compliance with the Act. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years, with a portion allocated for technical assistance. The Secretary shall oversee training and technical assistance funded through grants to ensure compliance with the Act, with a portion allocated for technical assistance to help applicants prepare applications and financing packages. The Secretary of Agriculture must provide Congress with a progress report on the implementation of the amendments made by this Act within 1 year of funds being available, and annually thereafter.
